summary: This document is a chain of emails from May 2020 between the FBI NY CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team) and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) regarding the processing and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. It details challenges in handling terabytes of data from numerous devices, including computers, phones, and storage media, and coordinating the format for legal review and discovery. This document appears to be a page from a court filing or legal correspondence, likely a motion or letter, concerning the organization and transfer of digital evidence (devices and data dumps) in the Epstein case. It references a protective order and is addressed to an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The digital evidence being discussed was seized from his residences in New York and the US Virgin Islands following his arrest.

events.title: Previous property search
events.description: Mention of a July 2007 search on one of Epstein's properties, where 9 IDE hard drives were found and later discovered in his Manhattan apartment in 2019.

events.title: Epstein arrest and searches
events.description: Search warrants executed at Epstein's New York mansion and US Virgin Islands properties, resulting in the seizure of numerous digital devices.

locations: Island (likely referring to Little St. James, Epstein's private island)
keyFacts: The FBI seized terabytes of digital evidence from Epstein's properties, including phones, tablets, computers, servers, DVRs, cameras, and loose media (thumb drives, SD cards).
Evidence included 9 IDE hard drives from a July 2007 search that were found copied (3 sets of 3) in Epstein's Manhattan apartment.
The U.S. Attorney's Office needed the data in a specific format (loadable into Relativity) for taint review and discovery production, causing processing delays.
The data transfer and review were complicated by the COVID-19 pandemic, with FBI personnel reduced to one day a week in the office.
Over 1.1 million documents had been received by early 2020, but in a format that lacked critical linkages (e.g., emails to attachments) and proper attribution to source devices.
The document is subject to a protective order covering specific paragraphs (7, 8, 9, 10, 15, and 17).
It discusses the logistical challenge of tracking digital evidence, including devices, data dumps, and materials transferred.
The author requests a spreadsheet to organize every device, its dump status, and what materials are being transferred to avoid a 'total disaster' for review.
The correspondence is directed to an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York, indicating it is part of the federal prosecution.
The document is part of a larger file (EFTA00157144.pdf) and references specific Bates numbers (EFTA_00001974, EFTA_00001975).
